msContents.summary: A panegyric account of the life and sayings of the Imam ‘Alī, by Muhammad Salih Husain Tirmiz̲ī with theتخلصKashfī (d. A.H. 1061/ A.D. 1650 at Agra). The authoris a descendant of Niʻmat Allāh Valī, 1330?-1431 شاه نعمت الله ولى، سيد نور الدين and the son of the Sufi Mīr ‘Abdullah Tirmizī Mushkīn Qalam (for a record of his life, miracles and utterances see the untitled Sufi treatise appended to Persian MS 094, (ff. 145b- 188a). He is alo the author of a well-known Sufi poem, theMajmu‘ah-yi Rāz (A.H. 1030, A.D. 1621). We are told by the author that it took him three years to write Mandqib-i Murtazavi, and that he intends to write Vjaz-i Mustafavii, a similar account of the life of the prophet Muhammad (f.291r):ان شاه الله العزیز بعد از اختتام, اعجاز مصطفی کتابی جداگانه در مناقب اصحاب مستطاب رضی الله عنهم اجمعین که مکنون خاطر است بمقتضای الهی در خبر (کذا) تحریر آورده بر صحیفه ظهور جلوه گر خواهد گردانید...ختم شد این نامه در قرب سه سال . However, Kashfī did not survive to accomplish his desire and the latter was to be completed by Mīr ‘Abd Allāh bin Mīr Hāshim shāh Ni‘mat allāh al-Husainī (see Rieu, BM 154a). In Manāqib-i Murtazavī Kashfī makes extensive use of the works of other authors, and relates stories some of which can be traced in other cultures long before the time of Imam ‘Ali, like the story of the man who is the victim of a cyclic tortur for his sin by being devoured by a bird and spat out to regain his life (f. 288b). It is mainly in prose, illustrated with verses by the author and selections from the works of other poets. provenance.p: From the collection ofColonel George William Hamilton (1807-1868)who served in India from 1823 to 1867 latterly as Commissioner in Delhi. He acquired over a thousand Indian and Persian manuscripts of which 352 were selected after his death for the British Museum. The remainder were purchased in 1868 byAlexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford.
